items.title: Odd issue with rename.py
items.body:
Hi there,

I'm not sure if this is quite the right place to ask this question (Because I'm not 100% which component is at fault) but I'm having the strangest stack trace from rope when trying to rename a variable.  Rope got installed by the vim plugin coc.nvim which provides language server capability for many languages including python.  

What's weird is that the stack trace seems to show that rope has discovered python files completely outside of my path and inside a VM on my machine which isn't even on the same OS (Linux rather than Windows).  It's erroring because those python files are in 2.7 format where the python on my machine is 3.8.

The stack trace looks like this:

[coc.nvim] Refactor failed. Syntax error in file <AppData/Local/Packages/CanonicalGroupLimited.Ubuntu18.04onWindows_79rh
kp1fndgsc/LocalState/rootfs/usr/lib/python2.7/lib2to3/pgen2/pgen.py> line <206>: Missing parentheses in call to 'print'.
 Did you mean print("Dump of NFA for", name)?
[
<FrameSummary file refactor.py, line 294 in watch>,
<FrameSummary file refactor.py, line 274 in _process_request>, 
<FrameSummary file refactor.py, line 206 in _rename>, 
<FrameSummary file refactor.py, line 117 in refactor>, 
<FrameSummary file refactor.py, line 139 in onRefactor>, 
<FrameSummary file C:\Users\Ben\AppData\Roaming\Python\Python38\site-packages\rope\refactor\rename.py, line 97 in get_changes>, 
<FrameSummary file C:\Users\Ben\AppData\Roaming\Python\Python38\site-packages\rope\refactor\rename.py, line 195 in rename_in_module>, 
<FrameSummary file C:\Users\Ben\AppData\Roaming\Python\Python38\site-packages\rope\refactor\occurrences.py, line 76 in find_occurrences>, 
<FrameSummary file C:\Users\Ben\AppData\Roaming\Python\Python38\site-packages\rope\base\utils\__init__.py, line 12 in _wrapper>, 
<FrameSummary file C:\Users\Ben\AppData\Roaming\Python\Python38\site-packages\rope\refactor\occurrences.py, line 392 in source_code>, 
<FrameSummary file C:\Users\Ben\AppData\Roaming\Python\Python38\site-packages\rope\base\utils\__init__.py, line 12 in _wrapper>, 
<FrameSummary file C:\Users\Ben\AppData\Roaming\Python\Python38\site-packages\rope\refactor\occurrences.py, line 412 in pymodule>, 
<FrameSummary file C:\Users\Ben\AppData\Roaming\Python\Python38\site-packages\rope\base\project.py, line 116 in get_pymodule>, 
<FrameSummary file C:\Users\Ben\AppData\Roaming\Python\Python38\site-packages\rope\base\pycore.py, line 142in resource_to_pyobject>, 
<FrameSummary file C:\Users\Ben\AppData\Roaming\Python\Python38\site-packages\rope\base\pycore.py, line 254 in get_pymodule>, 
<FrameSummary file C:\Users\Ben\AppData\Roaming\Python\Python38\site-packages\rope\base\pyobjectsdef.py, line 162 in __init__>, 
<FrameSummary file C:\Users\Ben\AppData\Roaming\Python\Python38\site-packages\rope\base\pyobjectsdef.py, line 191 in _init_source>]

So what's going on?  It's almost as though something was missing, and a filesystem search was started for the .py file.

items.title: Rename.get_old_name() can't identify objects name
items.body:
I tried to perform `Rename` refactoring in VIM and it leads to python process and VIM being frozen. I found that when rope is unable to identify old name and VIM refactoring dialog shows `[]`, every try leads to frozen vim. I reproduced small case, when `get_old_name()` returns empty string. Problem here is with renaming `SomeClass`:

`rope_rename.py`:
```
import rope.base.project
from rope.refactor.rename import Rename
from rope.base import libutils

myproject = rope.base.project.Project(".")
resource = libutils.path_to_resource(myproject, "foobar.py")
rename = Rename(myproject, resource, offset=190)
print(rename.get_old_name())
```
`foobar.py`:
```
import factory

class SomeFactory(factory.Factory):
    class Meta:
        model = dict

    pk = factory.Sequence(lambda x: x)
    name = factory.Sequence(lambda x: f"team-{x}")


class SomeClass:
    def __init__(self):
        if team_count % 2:
            raise TypeError("Some error")
```
Env:
`Python 3.6.8`
`factory_boy==2.12.0`

items.title: Rope renames variable incorrectly
items.body:
I've come across with this issue while using Rope as a library.

Python version: 3.7.6
OS: Ubuntu 18.04
Rope Version: 0.16.0

I also noticed this bug does not occur on Rope version 0.14.0

## How to reproduce the error
1. Create the following file structure
```
app
├── run.py
└── my_app
|   ├── __init__.py
|   └── apis
|      └── __init__.py
|      └── my_namespace.py
```

```
#app/run.py
from my_app import app

if __name__ == '__main__':
    app.run(host='0.0.0.0')

#app/my_app/__init__.py
from flask import Flask
from flask_httpauth import HTTPBasicAuth, HTTPTokenAuth, MultiAuth

app = Flask(__name__)
auth = MultiAuth(HTTPBasicAuth(), HTTPTokenAuth('Bearer'))

from my_app.apis import api  # noqa
api.init_app(app)

#app/my_app/apis/__init__.py
from flask_restplus import Api
from apis.my_namespace import api as my_api


api = Api()
api.add_namespace(my_api)


#app/my_app/apis/my_namespace.py
from flask_restplus import Namespace, Resource
from my_app import auth

api = Namespace('somenamespace')


class MyClassA(Resource):
    @auth.login_required
    def delete(self):
        my_var = f"some value"


class MyClassB(Resource):
    @auth.login_required
    def get(self):
        pass


api.add_resource(MyClassA, '/class-a')
api.add_resource(MyClassB, "/class-b")
```

2. Create the script for renaming `auth` variable in `app/my_app/__init__.py`.
This script should be at the same level with app folder. Name it `renamer.py`.
```
from rope.base import libutils, project
from rope.refactor.rename import Rename


def main():
    my_project = project.Project("app")
    file = "app/my_app/__init__.py"
    file_as_res = libutils.path_to_resource(my_project, file)
    declaration = 115
    change_set = Rename(my_project, file_as_res,
                        declaration).get_changes("f162b77e780b")
    my_project.do(change_set)
    my_project.close()


if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
```

3. Call that script `python renamer.py`

## Expected Result
In the `app/my_app/apis/my_namespace.py` it should look like:
```
from flask_restplus import Namespace, Resource
from my_app import f162b77e780b

api = Namespace('somenamespace')


class MyClassA(Resource):
    @f162b77e780b.login_required
    def delete(self):
        my_var = f"some value"


class MyClassB(Resource):
    @f162b77e780b.login_required
    def get(self):
        pass


api.add_resource(MyClassA, '/class-a')
api.add_resource(MyClassB, "/class-b")
```
## Observed Result
```
from flask_restplus import Namespace, Resource
from my_app import f162b77e780b

api = Namespace('somenamespace')


class MyClassA(Resource):
    @f162b77e780b.login_required
    def delete(self):
        my_var = f"some value"


class MyClassB(Resource):
    @af162b77e780buth.login_required # <<<<---- notice here 
    def get(self):
        pass


api.add_resource(MyClassA, '/class-a')
api.add_resource(MyClassB, "/class-b")

```

items.title: Fix simple typo: sitaution -> situation
items.body:
There is a small typo in rope/base/project.py.
Should read `situation` rather than `sitaution`.

items.title: Compatibility with 2.6? Really?
items.body: I don’t think it is hasty to declare Python 2.6 unsupported (I am not saying anything yet about now almost dead 2.7).

items.title: Rename issue
items.body:
I created a simple project `project` with two files:
- test1.py
```
def some_method():
    return 'foo'


some_method()
```

- test2.py
```
from project.test1 import some_method


some_method()
```

I am renaming `some_method` in the following way:
```
from rope.refactor.rename import Rename
from rope.base import libutils

from rope.base.project import Project


project = Project('PATH/project/')
resource = libutils.path_to_resource(project, 'PATH/project/test1.py')
rename = Rename(project, resource, 10)
changeset = rename.get_changes('new_name', in_hierarchy=True, docs=True, unsure=True)
```

`changeset.changes` contains only one element with a change in test1.py, while I expect that usage in test2.py should be updated too.

The issue does not occur if I use relative import in test2.py, like:
```
from .test1 import some_method


some_method()
```

Then, `changeset.changes`  contains two elements and both files are modified.

items.title: Incorrect parent for BuiltinFunction that belongs to a builtin type
items.body:
Looks like there's an issue when trying to obtain a function's parent of a builtin type. From what I've seen, we're getting back the PyModule. Shouldn't we be getting the builtin type instead?

e.g.if a variable `foo` is of type `base.builtins.Dict`, then:

```
builtin_name = foo.get_attribute('keys')
py_function = builtin_name.get_object()
assert py_function.parent == foo # Returns false
assert type(py_function.parent) == BuiltinModule # Returns true
```

I can submit a PR with what _I think_ would fix this issue.

items.title: Relicense rope under LGPL
items.body:
Given https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-python/issues/3867 I would like to consider relicensing whole ``rope`` project under another license more accessible to editors/IDE desiring to use rope.

It is not only attempt to butter VS Code developers up, but truly plain GPL doesn't make sense much for the project, which is essentially a library. Despite what [some others say](https://www.gnu.org/philosophy/pragmatic.html), I don't think tricking somebody into free software by spreading infection is not The Right Thing to do, and so I would prefer to relicense under an non-infectious license.

The question remains which license to use. In order to lessen friction (and because I like it), I would suggest [LGPL3+](https://www.gnu.org/licenses/lgpl.html) because it is the up-to-date version closest to the current license, and thus hopefully least controversial.

I would like to ask all you listed below add a comment with your agreement (just +1 is enough, but please make a separate comment so we have record of your name) if you agree with this change to LGPL3+. If you don't agree or if you really want a different license, please, make a comment as well. Of course, I give my +1 by filing this issue now.

This list should be hopefully list of all people who have more than two commits in the tree. If you are a committer and you are not listed below, please, let us know as well.

Thank you.

items.title: Refactor-renames often fail iff numpydoc is installed
items.body:
This issue has been noticed by some users of visual studio code which uses rope for its refactoring (eg https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-python/issues/500).

With this example py file,
```python
class MyClass():
    def __init__(self, A):
        self.A = A

    def bb(self, b):
        self.b = b
        pass

    def CC(self):
        pass
```
Trying to refactor `b` gives a lengthy error stacktrace that exits rope at this line: https://github.com/python-rope/rope/blob/18a204c65109b50083d57f611e7090d3cfe7b761/rope/base/oi/type_hinting/providers/numpydocstrings.py#L20

The remainder of the stacktrace is (e.g.),
```('/home/matt/anaconda3/envs/test2/lib/python2.7/site-packages/numpydoc/docscrape.py', 138, '__init__', "docstring = textwrap.dedent(docstring).split('\\n')")

('/home/matt/anaconda3/envs/test2/lib/python2.7/textwrap.py', 390, 'dedent', "text = _whitespace_only_re.sub('', text)")
```

with the exception message being `expected string or buffer` in Python 2.7 and `expected string or bytes-like object` in Python 3.5 and 3.6 (these are the versions I tested).

So the issue is with the calls rope sends to numpydoc, or maybe some further-upstream issue with numpydoc itself.

But note that in the rope file we have the lines https://github.com/python-rope/rope/blob/18a204c65109b50083d57f611e7090d3cfe7b761/rope/base/oi/type_hinting/providers/numpydocstrings.py#L10-L13 that mean hitting the failing line of code is contingent on numpydoc being importable.

If numpydoc is not installed, the above refactor works as requested.

items.title: you can even tell rope not to create .ropeproject folder
items.body:
> Rope uses a folder inside projects for holding project configuration and data. Its default name is .ropeproject, but it can be changed (you can even tell rope not to create this folder).
https://github.com/python-rope/rope/blob/master/docs/overview.rst#id1

How can I tell to `rope` to not create the `.ropeproject` folder everywhere, every time?

I use rope as a plugin on the https://github.com/palantir/python-language-server, currently it is instantiated like this: https://github.com/palantir/python-language-server/blob/099eb3691b3b90569f473ed920bb6045b06ff561/pyls/workspace.py#L84-L86
```python
File: python-language-server/pyls/workspace.py
84:         # Whilst incubating, keep private
85:         self.__rope = Project(self._root_path)
```

And on the `Project` constructor, we see this:
https://github.com/python-rope/rope/blob/5f84456acae0f67130a862110b7913b43b013724/rope/base/project.py#L191-L214

It is creating the `.ropeproject` folder anyway, independing of the constructor parameters.

Related:

https://github.com/palantir/python-language-server/issues/230 Maybe we should prevent creating a .ropeproject/config.py

items.title: Rename of module does not handle import aliases correctly
items.body:
I am using rope to rename modules in my project and came across a problem with how it handles aliases. Here is a minimal example that shows this behavior. In this case, `mod2.py` imports `mod1.py` and so should import `mod1.py` with a new name when `mod1.py`'s name is changed. However, in this case no changes are actually made in `mod2.py`. I am using version 0.10.7.

Here is my example:
```python
from rope.refactor.rename import Rename
from rope.base.project import Project

project = Project('.')

mod1 = project.root.create_file('mod1.py')
mod1.write(
    'class Test(object):\n'
    '    def __init__(self):'
    '        print "hello world"')

mod2 = project.root.create_file('mod2.py')
mod2string = 'import mod1 as m\n' + 'm.Test()'
mod2.write(mod2string)

new_name = 'AAAAAAAA'
changes = Rename(project, mod1).get_changes(new_name)
project.do(changes)

expected = 'import ' + new_name + ' as m\n' + 'm.Test()'
with open('mod2.py', 'r') as f:
    actual = f.read()
print '~' * 50
print actual
print '~' * 50
print expected
assert  actual == expected

```
I get the following output
```
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
import mod1 as m
m.Test()
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
import AAAAAAAA as m
m.Test()

---------------------------------------------------------------------------
AssertionError                            Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-52-b92f47d557f0> in <module>()
     25     print '~' * 50
     26     print expected
---> 27     assert  actual == expected
     28 

AssertionError: 
```

items.title: Support f"literal {string} interpolation" (PEP-498, Python 3.6)
items.body:
Seems like `rope` does not yet support rename variables in [literal string interpolations (PEP-498)](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0498/)  (included since Python 3.6), e.g. renaming `var` in `f"this {var} is interpolated"`. Tested it with [VSCode's Python extension](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-python) which uses `rope` underneaths.

Simple test: Rename `abc`

```python
#!/usr/bin/env python3.6

abc = "hello"

print(f"{abc}")
```

```python
some_name()
```

I can run a rename factoring from `some_name` to `some_other_name`.

But if I do something like this like this:
```python
import asyncio

def some_name():
    return 42

loop = asyncio.get_event_loop()
loop.run_until_complete(some_name())
```

and try the same refactoring, I get a `RefactoringError`:
```
  File "/Users/abingham/.virtualenvs/traad/lib/python3.6/site-packages/rope/refactor/multiproject.py", line 26, in __call__
    self.addpath, project, *args, **kwds)
  File "/Users/abingham/.virtualenvs/traad/lib/python3.6/site-packages/rope/refactor/multiproject.py", line 42, in __init__
    self.refactoring(other, *args, **kwds))
  File "/Users/abingham/.virtualenvs/traad/lib/python3.6/site-packages/rope/refactor/rename.py", line 28, in __init__
    'Rename refactoring should be performed'
rope.base.exceptions.RefactoringError: Rename refactoring should be performed on resolvable python identifiers.
```

Should rope work with this code? Am I missing something?

(FWIW, I'm doing the refactoring through traad, but I don't see how that would interfere with rope's support for the language.)

```
from oldmod import foo

from oldmod import bar
```

```
from oldmod import foo
from oldmod import bar


#todo bar needs something extra
```

items.title: import reordering breaks import cycle mitigation
items.body:
while moving a package around using a script with rope, rope moved one of my import statements from the end of a module to the start of a module,

however this import statement was placed intentionally there to work around a import cycle

an illustrative example `__init__.py`

```
import oldmod
class Base(oldmod.MagicObject):
   ...

from . import others
```
gets turned into 

```
import newmod

from . import others
class Base(newmod.MagicObject):
   ...

```

items.title: Broken RE for finding line starts
items.body:
This RE[0] seems to break on lines which contain an escaped `\` at the end of a string, e.g:

```
buffer.replace('\\', '%5C')
```

I believe it doesn't consider this to be a "close string" token (because there is a preceding "\" and so it confuses the syntax on the rest of the file.

[0] https://github.com/python-rope/rope/blob/master/rope/base/codeanalyze.py#L133

items.title: RopeRestructure bug
items.body:
I'm using the python-rope/ropevim vim plugin and find a bug:

pattern: `assert_true(${param})`
goal: `assert ${param}`

input: `assert_true(abs(lower[i + 0] - 87.7086) < 1e-3)`
unexpected output: `assert abs(lower[i + 0] - 87.7086) < 1e`

the output should be `assert abs(lower[i + 0] - 87.7086) < 1e-3`

---

Update: another similar bad case

pattern: `assert_equals(${param1}, ${param2})`
goal: `assert ${param1} == ${param2}`

input: `assert_equals(r, -100)`
unexpect output: `assert r == 100`

the output should be `assert r == -100`

items.title: Question: Contributing to the devel brach for Python 3.5
items.body:
@mcepl, I'm in the process of trying to resolve the issues in rope library when running under Python 3.5.
So far I've made two PRs.
Over the next few weeks/months, more issues will be fixed (that's the intent), hence more PRs will be submitted. 

I'm going to assume that most of the future fixes will rely on older fixes that I may have made. for instance the PR #169 is crucial to getting #170 working. However if I keep adding all the changes to the same PR it could get quite complicated for you to review the changes.

Let me know what you prefer.
- Keep updating the original PR #169 with new fixes (feels like the best solution in my opinion). However when you start reviewing you could have a who lot of files, and it would be best if you inform me when you start reviewing, so I can pause submitting more changes to the same PR)
- Create news PRs for each fix (however fixes from previous PRs will have to be added into them to ensure unit tests pass). This approach feels too complicated, but you'll have fewer changes to review.
- Or any other

items.title: undefined name 'ModuleSkipHandle'
items.body:
In `move.py` we have:

```
class ModuleSkipRenamer(object):                                                
    """Rename occurrences in a module                                           

    This class can be used when you want to treat a region in a file            
    separately from other parts when renaming.                                  

    """                                                                         

    def __init__(self, occurrence_finder, resource, handle=None,                
                 skip_start=0, skip_end=0, replacement=''):                     
        """Constructor                                                          

        if replacement is `None` the region is not changed.  Otherwise          
        it is replaced with `replacement`.                                      

        """                                                                     
        self.occurrence_finder = occurrence_finder                              
        self.resource = resource                                                
        self.skip_start = skip_start                                            
        self.skip_end = skip_end                                                
        self.replacement = replacement                                          
        self.handle = handle                                                    
        if self.handle is None:                                                 
            # ERROR: ModuleSkipHandle is UNDEFINED!!!                           
            self.handle = ModuleSkipHandle()                                    
```

items.title: MismatchedTokenError when using "except ... as" syntax.
items.body:
When trying to refactor in a file containing an except clause using the 'except ... as' syntax, Rope throws a MismatchedTokenError while parsing.

In the code sample below, attempting to extract line 3 (foo = [...]) as a method produces the given traceback.

Code sample:

``` python

class A:
    def spam(self):
        foo = [x**2 for x in range(10)]
        foo.reverse()
        return foo

try:
    print A().spam()
except Exception as e:
    print e
```

items.title: JobSet.finished_job incriments self.done too late
items.body:
While no one was looking, Lex Luthor took JobSet's ability to be 100% done in the eyes of observing functions. He took JobSet's ability to be one hundred percent done in the eyes of observing functions. That's as many as ten ten percents. And that's terrible. 

Read: Because self.done is incremented after `self.handle._inform_observers()` an observing function will never see `JobSet.get_percent_done() == 100`.

https://gist.github.com/7761137

items.title: "TypeError: must be str, not unicode" from Mercurial while renaming package

I'm not certain whether this is a Rope issue, or a Mercurial library issue: if it turns out to be the latter, i'll take the issue upstream.

items.title: ImportError: could not import name UserDict
items.body:
I was working with ropemacs and I got  a traceback to the file /usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/rope/base/oi/objectdb.py complaining that it couldn't import UserDict.

That file starts with "from collections import UserDict, MutableMapping". "from collections import UserDict" raises an exception on my machine (Fedora 16, python 2.7.2) so I changed the first lines of that file to:

from collections import MutableMapping

from UserDict import UserDict

And everything works fine so far.

items.title: distutils is not part of Python's standard library.
items.body:
Changeset [[https://bitbucket.org/agr/rope/changeset/b4e28f313b17|b4e28f313b17]] assumes distutils is installed, and that's not always the case, as distutils is not part of Python's standard library.

The change was for OS X specific workaround, but it should be enabled only for that platform (where distutils seems to be installed by default).

The older code was not ideal either, because it reported back the path to the stdlib of the interpreter actually running that function, and not the system wide interpreter.

Point in case: An editor that has an embedded Python interpreter, for which a plugin adds rope's support, would report, on Windows, for example, "python26.zip", while it would be better if it reported "c:\python26\libs" instead.

Maybe rope should allow this setting to be changed from the .ropeproject.py file. That seems the most general solution to me.

items.title: Allow PEP8 import re-organization
items.body:
PEP8 should be followed when re-organizing imports, meaning that if there are lots of imports, they shouldn't exceed the 80 character limit.

Also, there should be a configuration option that allows a one-import per line.
